instruction: [INST] Analyze this file to learn MacBook motherboard repair. The 'definitions' section explains key technical terms. The 'threads' section contains real-world repair discussions. Use both sections to understand and learn how to troubleshoot MacBook issues. Posts from username 'larossmann' , 'dukefawks' , and '2informaticos' are posts from trusted experts.[/INST]

definitions.820-3330: What is 820-3330? a LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER.
definitions.PPBUS_G3H: What is PPBUS_G3H? Main system power rail that charges the battery, or is power from the battery, that everything else is powered from. .
definitions.PM_SLP_S4_L: What is PM_SLP_S4_L? PM_SLP_S4_L is a signal that puts the system into an S4 suspend to disk sleep state when it is low(_L means signal is asserted when voltage is low).
definitions.PP3V42_G3H: What is PP3V42_G3H? PP3V42_G3H is a power rail present when the machine is in a G3H global system hardware off state and is the first rail that should be generated in Macbooks that use it. .
definitions.PP5V_S5: What is PP5V_S5? This is a 5v power rail that is present when the machine is in an S5 soft off state..
definitions.PP5V_S0: What is PP5V_S0? PP5V_S0 is a 5v power rail present when the system is in an S0 working state..
definitions.PPVRTC_G3H: What is PPVRTC_G3H? PPVRTC_G3H is a 3.3v power rail for the RTC circuit present when the machine is in a G3H global system hardware off state. .
definitions.PP5V_S3: What is PP5V_S3? PP5V_S3 is a 5v power rail present when the system is in an S3 suspend to RAM state..
definitions.PP3V3_S0: What is PP3V3_S0? The "PP3V3_S0" rail in a MacBook logic board is a power rail that supplies 3.3 volts to the system when it is fully awake (S0 state). .
definitions.PP1V05_S0:
What is PP1V05_S0? The PP1V05_S0 power rail is for various components on the logic board that require a 1.05V supply voltage in the S0 (on) state. This voltage rail is likely to be used by the CPU (for VCCIO), PCH (Platform Controller Hub).

.
definitions.PP1V8_S0: What is PP1V8_S0? PP1V8_S0 is a power rail that is present when the machine is in an S0 state, meaning it is fully turned on, not sleeping or hiberating .
definitions.MEMVTT_EN_L: What is MEMVTT_EN_L? MEMVTT_EN_L is a signal that enables memory VTT voltage power rail when it is low.  _L means whatever before the _L in the signal name is asserted when it is low voltage, such as 0.0v to 0.5v..

threads.title: <LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER>820-3330</LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER> green/orange light on magsafe, no fan spin
threads.message:
Hi,

I have been watching Louis' videos for some time now and finally got around to trying to troubleshoot what's wrong with my 2012 15" Unibody Macbook Pro.

I am new to this so I don't really know where to start diagnosing. I have some donor boards which I can take components off of.

One thing to note is plugging in the charger, even for 5 minutes, the board gets really hot which makes me believe I have a short somewhere.

Can anyone please provide some tips as to where to start from so I can hopefully find the root of the problem?

threads.title: <LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER>820-3330</LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER> green/orange light on magsafe, no fan spin
threads.message:
<SIGNAL>PPCHGR_DCIN</SIGNAL> = 16.8v
<SIGNAL>PP3V42_G3H</SIGNAL> = 3.41v
<SIGNAL>PPBUS_G3H</SIGNAL> IS 12.02v and rising slowly .01 steps
<SIGNAL>PPVRTC_G3H</SIGNAL> = 3.35v
<SIGNAL>PP5V_S3</SIGNAL> = 5.07v
PM_SLP_S3_ = 3.32v
<SIGNAL>PP3V3_S0_PCH</SIGNAL> = 3.33v
<SIGNAL>PP5V_S5</SIGNAL> = 5.07v
<SIGNAL>PM_SLP_S4_L</SIGNAL> = 3.33v
<SIGNAL>MEMVTT_EN</SIGNAL> = Not present
<SIGNAL>MEMVTT_EN_L</SIGNAL> = 5.07v
<SIGNAL>PP3V3_S0</SIGNAL> = 3.34v
<SIGNAL>PP5V_S0</SIGNAL> = 5.07v
<SIGNAL>PP1V8_S0</SIGNAL> = 1.80v
<SIGNAL>PP1V05_S0</SIGNAL> = 0.09v

threads.title: <LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER>820-3330</LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER> green/orange light on magsafe, no fan spin
threads.message:
No Title

So I decided to take the board out of the chassis. About time, yes I know..

I found a burnt chip indicated in the photos

Can someone indicate what could be the cause? As I have a donor board and can swap it out but I don't want to burn that one as well if there is something else wrong on the board

threads.title: <LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER>820-3330</LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER> green/orange light on magsafe, no fan spin
threads.message:
My initial problem was that I knocked off a resistor which is connected to a capacitor which connects to CPUVCCIOS0_LL which are 3 of the pins on the chip burned. That resistor is now back in place. Could the problem have something to do with that?

Since the resistor was knocked off there shouldn't have been any current flowing. So I don't believe the chip got more voltage or amperage than it's used to.

threads.title: <LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER>820-3330</LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER> green/orange light on magsafe, no fan spin
threads.message:
"Since the resistor was knocked off there shouldn't have been any current flowing."
Wrong asumption, that resistor is from bootstrap circuit of high-side MOSFET (<TRANSISTOR>Q7630</TRANSISTOR>); it got burnt because of high RdsON.
N-channel MOSFET requires 5V G-S (PWM signal amplitude) for properly working.
If bootstrap circuit doesn't work, the amplitude is very low, increasing RdsON a lot...

Remove burnt MOSFET and check low-side one (<TRANSISTOR>Q7635</TRANSISTOR>) for short.
I recommend you to change <CHIP>U7600</CHIP> too.
Be sure that <RESISTOR>R7630</RESISTOR> has correct 0ohm value and <CAPACITOR>C7630</CAPACITOR> is still in place.

threads.title: <LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER>820-3330</LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER> green/orange light on magsafe, no fan spin
threads.message:
How do I check a mosfet for short? I have never done this before
Also the <RESISTOR>R7630</RESISTOR> when testing on Ohm mode 200 it comes up with 00.2 or 00.3 is this good?

Thank you for taking your time to help me

threads.title: <LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER>820-3330</LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER> green/orange light on magsafe, no fan spin
threads.message:
Less than 0.5ohms is OK.
That low value is because of multimeter leads resistance; you will never get 0.0ohms.

threads.title: <LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER>820-3330</LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER> green/orange light on magsafe, no fan spin
threads.message: High side FET on VCCIO is shorted out. This will have killed the CPU and or PCH already. This board is RIP.

threads.title: <LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER>820-3330</LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER> green/orange light on magsafe, no fan spin
threads.message:
[QUOTE="dukefawks, post: 39310"]High side FET on VCCIO is shorted out. This will have killed the CPU and or PCH already. This board is RIP.[/QUOTE]


Is this a possibility or 100% sure? How can I test to see if the CPU or PCH are actually burned? Thanks

threads.title: <LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER>820-3330</LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER> green/orange light on magsafe, no fan spin
threads.message: I have never had a CPU survive this so unless you have time to waste this is a very unlikely repair. There is no way to test the CPU besides fixing the board and hoping it works.
